Graphical abstract An impregnation method was used to develop a reusable and highly active heterogeneous catalyst (Cs x Zr y /Al2O3) with different Cs/Zr molar ratio (0.3≤ x, y ≤0.7). The catalyst activity was evaluated in the transesterification of waste cooking oil (WCO) with methanol for the synthesis of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs). A typical Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was characterized for physical and chemical properties in terms of the amount of FAME produced. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method, X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, basic strength analysis, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy were utilized in the characterization of the catalysts. The effects of different process variables of transesterification reaction, such as methanol-to-WCO ratio (10:1–30:1), catalyst amount (1w/w–5w/w oil), and reaction time (1–5h), on the catalyst performance were investigated. During 3h reaction time 90%FAME content was produced at 65°C with 20:1 methanol-to-WCO molar ratio and 3wt.% catalyst loading. Results of the reusability tests indicated that the solid catalyst can be re-used for four batch cycles. Also, the catalyst exhibited good tolerance toward 0.8w.% water, without significant changes in the FAME content. Keywords Fatty acid methyl esters Transesterification Waste cooking oil Mixed-oxide 1 Introduction The synthesis of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) from vegetable oils and animal fats can be used an alternative solution to the current reliance on diesel fuel [1]. FAMEs exhibit non-toxic combustion with low emission profiles, characterizing their biodegradability [2,3]. FAMEs are relatively safe and environmentally friendly compared with petroleum diesel [4]. Alternative energy sources and raw materials are being given considerable attention because of the growing environmental concern regarding nonrenewable natural resources [5]. Given that diesel fuel is limited, developed and developing countries are searching for renewable fuel resources [6,7]. FAMEs are synthesized by transesterification reaction of triglyceride feedstock with methanol in the presence of a catalyst. To produce biodiesel fuel, a number of oils are utilized, such as soybean oil, sunflower oil, coconut oil, tobacco seed oil, palm and palm kernel oils, and animal fats [8–12]. Waste vegetable cooking oil (WCO) is considered an alternative source with a high rate of annual disposal from restaurants, thereby assuring a continuous supply of feedstock for conversion to methyl esters [1,13]. In addition, WCO utilization reduces environmental pollution. In searching for other potential sources in producing FAMEs, WCO is converted through catalytic process where a catalyst is used as transesterification facilitator at suitable operating parameters, thereby decreasing production cost [14]. Several heterogeneous catalysts have been evaluated in the transesterification of vegetable oils for biodiesel production [15,16]. Heterogeneous catalysts are preferred for biodiesel production because they are reusable and their reaction products can be easily separated [17]. Moreover, they exhibit high activity, long life time, and high tolerance to water and free fatty acids [18]. Reactions involving heterogeneous catalysts should be performed under high temperatures to improve conversion into desired products; in some cases, complex, rare, and expensive preparatory procedures are needed [19]. To achieve high biodiesel yield, high reaction temperature and high pressure or toxic solvent are employed [20]. Tantirungrotechai [21] developed the heterogeneous catalyst calcium-incorporated MCM-41 synthesis for transesterification of palm olein and achieved 90wt.% of FAME yield; the catalyst preparation is expensive and the reaction was performed a thigh temperature (200°C). Kazemian et al. used Cs-modified mesoporous silica for canola oil transesterification. They found that under atmospheric pressure (at 65°C), the transesterification reaction does not produce considerable amounts of biodiesel product (1.05% FAME conversion) and the reaction is extremely slow at lower temperature and pressure. However, increasing the reaction temperature to 135°C resulted in 25.35% FAME conversion [22]. Sun et al. synthesized mesoporous Ca/SBA-15 solid base for transesterification of sunflower oil. When 0.5wt.% of calcium is loaded on the SBA-15, the biodiesel yield reaches as high as 99.1% at 200°C reaction temperature for 8h [19]. Recently mixed oxide supported catalyst have shown promise for oil transesterification reaction mainly waste cooking oils [23–27]. Hindryawati et al. [27] studied different metal oxides containing lithium, sodium, and potassium supported rice husk silica as catalysts for waste cooking oil transesterification. The mixed alkali metal silicate catalysts showed longer lasting activity than the traditional alkali catalysts. The process was able to transesterify oil to methyl esters in the up to 98.2% at 65°C during 1h reaction time. Develop of bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts was studied for waste cooking oil transesterification by Farooq et al. [26]. Among the different catalysts tested, the aluminum supported Mo–Mn mixed oxide catalyst provides the maximum yield of 91.4% at 100°C during 4h reaction time and 27:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio. These results prove mixed metal oxide on support contribute the internal diffusion of the large triglyceride molecule into the catalyst pores catalysts [28]. In this study, to solve these issues, solid-mixed oxide Al2O3-supported catalysts of Cs x Zr y /Al2O3 (0.3≤ x, y ≤0.7) were synthesized and their ability to catalyze the transesterification of WCO from palm oil was evaluated. The variations in the textural and structural characteristics of the prepared catalysts with the change in atomic composition were investigated. The reaction was investigated under a wide range of parameters, and the catalyst was tested for water content resistance, possible leaching and potential reusability. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3), zirconium chloride (ZrOCl2·8H2O), and gamma alumina (Al2O3) used to prepare the catalyst, were purchase from Sigma–Aldrich Co. (Malaysia). The WCO used was collected from a cafeteria in the Engineering Campus of the University of Science Malaysia. The WCPO fatty acid compositions were determined by Perkin Elmer Clarus 600 GCMS equipped with Elite-5MS capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25mm) (Table 1 ), while the physical properties such as density, water content, and acid value were analyzed based on EN ISO 3675, ENISO 12937 and EN 14104 methods, respectively (Table 2 ). HPLC-grade methanol used for the transesterification reactions was purchased from Merck Co. (Malaysia). Reference standards for gas chromatography analysis were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich Co. (Malaysia). All reagents were applied without any further treatments. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The aluminum-supported catalysts Cs x Zr y /Al2O3 with different cesium and zirconium atomic ratios (0.3≤ x, y ≤0.7) were synthesized by the impregnation method. The metals dissolved in a mixture of 50:50 (v/v) deionized water and ethanol solution were impregnated on the aluminum support. To obtain 5g of the catalyst, a solution containing the calculated amounts of metal salts, depending on atomic ratio, was prepared for 24h under constant stirring to induce contact between the support and solution (2ml/g support). With the use of a rotary evaporator, the excess solution was removed and the obtained catalyst was washed excessively with deionized water followed by drying at 110°C for 2h. The dried catalysts were calcined between the 250 and 450°C at 5°C/min heating rate and 4h dwelling [29]. The optimal calcination temperature (350°C) was used in the subsequent experimental runs (Section 3.3.1). Similarly, unsupported Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 catalyst was prepared using impregnation method in which desired amounts of their salts were dissolved in a mixture of 50:50 (v/v) deionized water and ethanol solution. In a typical batch preparation, based on 5g of the final catalyst, a solution containing 4M of Cs2CO3, and 3M of ZrOCl2 was prepared according to the ratio of their combination in the formula expression. Afterwards, the obtained mixture was mixed at 600rpm for one day to obtain a mixed solution. The temperature of the mixture was maintained at 30°C during stirring. At the end of mixing, the solution was separated by rotary evaporator and the obtained catalyst was washed with deionized water followed by drying at 110°C for 2h. The dried catalysts were calcined at the optimal calcination temperature (350°C) with 5°C/min heating rate and 4h dwelling. After that unsupported catalyst was prepared from their salts adopting the above procedure and used for transesterification of WCO with methanol. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The total surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the synthesized catalysts were evaluated using the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −197°C via the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) method utilizing Micrometrics ASAP 2020 V3.02H Micrometritics instrument. Hammett indicators method was used to determine the basic strengths of the catalysts (H_). Approximately 25mg of the catalyst sample was diluted with methanol and shaken with 5.0ml of a solution of Hammett indicators, and then left to equilibrate for 2h. After the equilibration, the color on the suspension was recorded. The following Hammett indicators were used: neutral red (H_=6.8), bromothymol blue (H_=7.2), phenolphthalein (H_=9.3), 2, 4-dinitroaniline (H_=15.0), and 4-nitroaniline (H_=18.4). The surface functional groups were identified using Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The FTIR spectra for the as-synthesized catalysts were obtained using Perkin Elmer System 2000 spectrometer via the standard KBr disk method. The spectra were recorded in the fingerprint region of 2000cm−1 to 400cm−1. Wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a diffractometer (Riga ku Rix 3000, S/N RR 21003, Japan) to investigate the structure and the unit cell parameters of the synthesized catalysts. The Cu Kα radiation electrons (λ =1.5406Å) were accelerated at 30kV and 10mA in an evacuated X-ray tube with Ni filter, and EVA software was used to analyze the data. The main metallic amounts of catalyst with or without support were obtained by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) using a Quanta FEG 450 model field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) instrument. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was implemented with a 200kV TECNAI G 20 S-TWIN FEI equipped with a field emission source. The point-to-point resolution was 0.19nm and the resolution between lines was 0.14nm. The samples were grounded and deposited on holey-carbon-coated grids from ultrasonicated ethanol suspensions. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The transesterification reaction of WCO with methanol was conducted in a 120ml round-bottom glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The appropriate amounts of methanol and catalyst, 23mL methanol and 0.73g of catalyst, were determined on the basis of the methanol-to-oil molar ratio; 27mL oil was added to the reactor. The reactor was attached to a water-cooled condenser, and the mixture was heated at 65°C and vigorously stirred for 3h. After the set time, the catalyst was separated from the product mixture by centrifugation. The FAMEs were analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu 2010 Plus, Japan) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID-2010 Plus) and capillary column (Nukol; 15m length, 0.53mm internal diameter, and 0.5μm film thickness). The column temperature varied from 110°C to 190°C (10min) at 10°C/min ramp. The FID and injection temperature were set at 220 and 250°C, respectively. Helium was used as the carrier gas. Methyl heptadecanoate was used as the internal standard. Then, 1μL of the sample was injected and FAME content was calculated using the following equation [30]: F A M E % = ∑ A − A E I A E I × C E I ⋅ V E I m × 100 ∑A: Total peak area of the methyl ester in C14 to that in C24:1; A EI : Peak corresponding to methyl heptadecanoate; C EI : Concentration of the methyl heptadecanoate solution (mgmL−1); V EI : Volume of the methyl heptadecanoate solution (mL); M: Mass of the sample (mg). 2.5 Catalyst stability The transesterification reaction of WCO was conducted employing 20:1 methanol-to-oil molar ratio, 65°C reaction temperature for 3h and 3wt.% catalyst loading to determine catalyst reusability. Filtration process was used to separate the catalyst from the reaction mixture; methanol and hexane were used in washing the filtrate, which was then dried at 110°C for 2h. The catalyst was reused in the subsequent run without further treatment. To verify the catalyst stability, 0.73g catalyst was stirred with 23mL methanol at 65°C for 3h. WCO (27mL) was then added to the methanol mixture, and transesterification reaction was performed under the optimal conditions (65°C for 3h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Textural properties and surface basicity (base amount) The textural characteristics of the aluminum-supported (CsxZry/Al2O3) and unsupported (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2) catalysts are shown in Table 3 . According to the obtained results, the BET surface area values of supported catalysts are higher than that of Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 (6.9m2 g−1). This observation could be attributed to the role of aluminum as support, which improved the textural properties of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 catalyst (Table 3). Amani et al. [31] loaded calcium oxide and zirconium oxides on aluminum support to amplify catalyst surface area, which resulted in the production of high FAME content in the transesterification reaction. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the catalysts (Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 and Cs0.6Zr0.4 O2) are presented in Fig. 1 . Both of the obtained isotherms exhibit type IV with type H2 hysteresis loops, which are characteristics of mesoporous materials [32]. This type of hysteresis loops represents regular distributions of the pore structure, size, and shape of materials. Further, the textural parameters of the support catalysts could be changed by loading the cesium and zirconium into the Al2O3 framework. The decrease in the surface area was more considerable when the amount of zirconium loaded was increased, whereas pore volume decreased. This marked decrease may be attributed to the partial blockage of the pore wall micropore. The surface area of different loading of Cs x Zr y /Al2O3 shows that surface area, pore size, and pore volume was effected by the amount of metal loading. The basic strength of the catalyst active sites represents distinctive factor for the transesterification reaction. As such, the basic properties were investigated using the Hammet indicator method [33]. The unsupported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2) exhibits a higher specific basicity than the supported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3) because of the decreased number of available protons responsible for acidity [34]. Also the basicity increased with increased cesium metal loading; however, the surface area and catalyst structure was partially changed after metal loading. It was observed that Cs0.7Zr0.3/Al2O3 and Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 achieved the highest basic strength (9.3<H_<15). It was found that the basic strength of the prepared supported catalyst was improved after coating with cesium and then further increased by loading of cesium over the Zr/Al2O3. The basic strength of the prepared catalysts was noted to be in the following order; Cs0.4Zr0.6/Al2O3 <Cs0.5Zr0.5/Al2O3 Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 <Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 ≈Cs0.7Zr0.3/Al2O3. These observations suggested that combination of cesium and zirconium was directly affected the basic strength of the catalysts. Ayoub et al. [33] reported increased basicity site of clay after modification with lithium. In the current study, the catalytic basicity was affected by the use of supported catalysts (Table 3). This result is consistent with that in several studies, confirming that the catalytic activity mainly depends on the nature of the active sites [35–37]. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The possibility of achieving close interaction between metals and support at the quasi-molecular level is a typical feature of the impregnation method for supported catalysts, hindering the formation of large crystalline domains [38]. Comprehensive studies are available on the synthesis of supported mixed oxide catalyst via various preparation method, such as co-precipitation, sol–gel, hydrothermal, electrochemical deposition, and salt oxide methods [3,39–41]. Among these methods, impregnation is a relatively simple and effective method in producing a crystalline phase under mild synthesis conditions. Fig. 2 (a) shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts to confirm the morphological structure of the Cs x Zr y -based catalysts. With regard to the composition, the different metal ratios of the catalysts are characterized by broad signals in the 2θ range between 20° and 80°. The Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 mixed oxide catalyst formed a monoclinic spinel cesium zirconium oxide (Fig. 2(a)a), indicating high level of incorporated metal. The diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 22.3°, 25.4°, 29.9°, 49.9°, and 54.4° correspond to the Cs4ZrO4 and used to evaluate the effect of metallic content on the crystallographic phase of the supported catalyst with varied metallic contents; the XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 2(a)b–f. The Cs0.7Zr0.3O2/Al2O3 catalyst showed higher degree of Cs6Al2O6crystallinity, indicated by the increased intensity of the corresponding peaks because the Cs0.7Zr0.4O2catalyst contained higher amount of Cs+2 than the other catalysts. As such, the typical ZrAlO2peaks were decreased with the increase in Cs+2. In addition, Fig. 2(a)a–e shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts with the intensity peaks at 2θ of 19.3°, 25.5° and 55° corresponding to Cs6Zr7O17, peaks at 2θ values of 37.4°, 50.4°, 67.4°and 72.7° assigned toZrAlO2 and intensity peaks at 2θ values of 19.3°, 33°, 45° and 65° corresponding to Cs6Al2O6. The XRD pattern of the fresh catalyst (before being used in the transesterification reaction) was compared with the spent catalyst (after being used four times in the transesterification reaction). The spent catalyst showed similar spectrum (Fig. 2(b)), but the additional peaks were observed at 17°, 26°, and 28.5°that are corresponding to different structure of zirconium aluminum oxide (Zr3Al2O). The differences observed in these spectra and the structures are believed to be the consequence of the activity of the catalyst in transesterification. Similar strong peaks for the used catalyst were represented by strong peaks for the fresh catalyst. The catalytic activity during transesterification varies in these spectra and structures. The observed results are assigned based on existing data from previous studies [41–43]. The XRD patterns validated the new observed peaks in the FTIR spectrum of the reused catalyst. On the basis of the above results, the interaction between the metal cations in the supported catalyst and the formation of crystalline phase caused by certain ions (i.e., Cs3+ and Zr2+) were helpful in increasing the catalytic activity (Section 3.2). The FTIR spectra provide additional information and evidence on the molecular banding of metal oxide-supported catalysts. 3.1.3 Fourier transform infrared analysis (FTIR) Fig. 3(a) shows the results of the functional group characterization (FTIR) of the prepared samples. In general, the FTIR spectra of the catalysts contain four vibrations of the external water molecules in addition to the metaloxygen and metalOH stretching bands. The FTIR spectrum of Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 illustrates seven distinct peaks at approximately 560, 730, 840, 1000, 1400, 1600 and 3600cm−1 (Fig. 3(a)a). The band at approximately840cm−1 corresponded to the characteristic CsO bonding, whereas the bands at 535 and 684cm−1 indicated the Zr3+ O2 and ZrO vibrations, respectively [44]. Thus, the prepared composites are well coordinated and incorporated in the catalyst, forming a stable protective layer. The peak at approximately 1600cm−1 was due to δ (HOH) bending vibration of coordinated water molecules present in the interlayer structure. The wide absorption bands in the 3400cm−1 to 3600cm−1 region were assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric υ (OH) stretching of hydrogen-bonded water molecules [41]. Another band at approximately 1400cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibration of CCH2 groups. This band is known as the characteristic band of CH2 groups presented in triglyceride that was found with sample. The FTIR spectra of the other catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 3(a) b–f. The peaks at approximately 530, 700, and 1400cm−1 indicated the vibrational distortions of the CsO octahedral site, ZrO stretching mode site, and AlO, respectively. These peaks vary with the change in the metal ratio in the catalysts. Similar results are found in previous studies [40,41,45]. Sabri et al. [46] stated that changing of the metal ratio affects the FTIR spectra of alumina supported heteropolyacid catalyst at 800, 980, 1600 and 3500cm−1, which correspond to the metal structure. The FTIR observation results, along with the HRTEM (Fig. 5) and XRD analyses (Fig. 2(a)), demonstrate the crystalline nature of the synthesized catalysts. The FTIR spectrum comparison between fresh and reused catalyst (applied in reaction for four times) is presented in Fig. 3(b). The three bands observed at approximately 1258, 1443, and 2924cm−1 correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric CO2 stretching representing the CO or CO functional groups from the carboxylates, respectively. The observed alteration of the functional groups is due to the increment space charge polarization and crystal effects after transesterification reaction [31], which was confirmed by the XRD results. 3.1.4 Surface morphology (FESEM and HRTEM) Fig. 4 shows the FESEM micrograph of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 and Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 catalysts. The micrograph of the unsupported catalyst (Fig. 4(a)) exhibits spherical and cluster shapes ascribed to the cesium and zirconium oxide, respectively. The surface morphology of the supported catalyst (Fig. 4(b)) shows a closely packed arrangement of crystallites, which can be attributed to the destruction of bigger crystals into unit clustering of metal oxide particles on the alumina surface. Moreover, the catalyst exhibits a porous nature, which is also considered to be one of the reasons behind its high performance during the transesterification of WCO. The FESEM images are consistent with the results of BET analysis and in previous studies [47]. However, to obtain a detailed and accurate analysis of the porous structure, the prepared samples (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 and Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3) were further characterized by means of HRTEM analysis (Fig. 5). The crystallographic phases were identified principally by measuring the distances between the diffraction fringes. This method is specifically useful in the identification of crystalline mixed oxide zones on the catalysts because of the low-contrast phase between cesium and zirconium and similar morphology observed for the different crystalline phases [48]. Well-crystallized ZrO2 and CsO2 phases were identified on the as-prepared Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 (Fig. 5(a)). The same crystalline phases were also identified on the Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 5(b)). In addition, the existence of the fringes verified the incorporation of cesium and zirconium ions in the aluminum support, which concords with the XRD results. The HRTEM images of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 sample are illustrated in Fig. 5(a). The analysis indicated the existence of darker spots with roundish shape that belong to cesium and zirconium oxides; results of the EDX analysis also confirmed the composition of these particles. The effect of particle size of zirconium oxide and cesium oxide on the catalyst activity was particularly considered in the HRTEM analysis. Fig. 5(a) illustrates the particle size distribution at the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 surface (section b), which was obtained after measuring the statistical representative number of the particles. The size distribution is not dispersed, with the largest fraction of particles in the range of 1–1.9nm, resulting in an average diameter of 1.45nm. The discrepancy between the XRD and HRTEM results could be because the very small cesium particles may have been undetected by the XRD technique. Meanwhile, large cesium particles are difficult to observe because they exhibit highly similar contrast phase and size with zirconium. These particles could be easily detected by XRD because of the presence of coherent crystalline domains. Results of the HRTEM analysis of the supported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3) (Fig. 5(b), sections a and b) indicate a relatively high phase heterogeneity. Various mixed oxide phases were observed in the HRTEM images, which is consistent with the XRD patterns. In particular, Zr3O4, cubic CsO2, and Zr3CsO4 (section b) are intercalated by crystalline catalyst regions. These features indicate that cesium and zirconium coexist on the aluminum support and interact in well-combined phases. The metallic mixed oxides-rich zones were observed by evaluating the distance between the fringes images. Based on the HRTEM and the XRD results, the morphology features and the presence of metal particles with different sizes are responsible for the difference in catalytic behavior of Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 and Cs0.6Zr0.4O2. The results are consistent with the conclusion of Imran et al. [49] that studied the formation of highly dispersed mixed oxide catalyst for the chemical recycling of ethylene terephthalate. The effect of aluminum support in preventing metals agglomeration is more pronounced in the case of Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3. The role of the metal ratio should be emphasized because it accelerates the homogeneous dispersion of cesium and zirconium over the aluminum sites in the catalyst. Consequently, the higher activity of the Cs0.7Zr0.3O2/Al2O3 catalyst than the Cs0.7Zr0.3O2 could be related with the homogenous agglomeration of metals on the alumina support. 3.1.5 Elemental composition of the synthesized catalyst (EDX) To verify the existence of cesium and zirconium and their effect on the catalytic performance of the supported catalyst, EDX analysis was conducted. The Cs0.6Zr0.4O2 catalyst contained 71.96wt.% cesium, 13.45wt.% zirconium, 31.40wt.% oxygen, whereas the supported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3) contained 82.17wt.% cesium, 14.32wt.% zirconium, 41.33wt.% oxygen, and 5.59wt.% aluminum. The aluminum oxide, as a support, significantly increased the catalysis of the transesterification of WCO (Section 3.2). Amani et al. reported the element composition of CaZrAlO mixed oxide catalyst before and after transesterification reaction [50]. 3.2 Catalytic activity: transesterification of waste cooking oil with methanol In this study, the catalytic activity of the synthesized catalysts was defined by means of the produced FAME content. The effect of the interaction between the metals on the aluminum supported of the synthesized catalyst was investigated to obtain further insights into its performance during transesterification. Table 4 shows the activity of the 3wt.% catalyst loading with different metal ratios at 65°C for 3h reaction duration. For x <0.5, the catalytic activity showed higher FAME content compared with x >0.5. After 3h reaction time, the catalyst containing 3wt.% Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 achieved the highest FAME content (90%). The unsupported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2) exhibited catalyzed the WCO transesterification reaction, resulted 47% FAME content within 3h. Thus, the synergetic effects of the combined metal composite catalysts with alumina support are better under the treatment conditions. In this study, two recommendations were formulated: the use aluminum as support for mixed oxide; and increasing the Cs content in the catalyst. The use of aluminum support resulted in increased FAME content and the increase in Cs ratio within the main formulae (Cs x Zr y /Al2O3) doubles the effect of FAME content. These phenomena are attributed to the high surface basicity of the catalyst because of the presence of high cesium amount and the nature of the active sites (Section 3.1.1). By changing the x value of the formula, Mg1+ x Ca1− x O2, developed by Khayoon et al. [51], they also observed that the high catalytic activity is not only correlated with the basicity amount of the catalyst but also with other characteristics. After the preliminary evolution of the catalytic performance, detailed investigations were implemented to analyze the effects of different reaction parameters on the FAME content. With the use of the heterogeneous catalyst, the reaction temperature significantly affects the transesterification reactions. A temperature close to the methanol reflux temperature is preferable because of its economic values [16]. In the current study, WCO was used in the transesterification reaction at 65°C. Other reaction conditions were optimized, by varying the methanol-to-WCO molar ratio, catalyst amount, and reaction time, to increase the FAME content. 3.3 Effect of reaction parameters 3.3.1 Effect of calcination temperature The effect of calcination temperature on the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalytic performance in transesterification reaction was investigated. In this context, the catalyst was calcined at different temperatures (250–450°C). Fig. 6(a) shows the results of FAME content obtained using Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst calcined at varying temperatures for 4h dwelling time. As evidenced by the results the calcination temperature is a key factor affecting the performance of the catalyst. The FAME content increased from 62% to 90% as the calcination temperature changed from 250°C to 350°C for catalyst sample calcined for 4h dwelling. Increasing calcination temperature to 350°C resulted in a catalyst improvement performance in transesterification reaction. With further increase in the calcination temperature a decrease in FAME content was observed, indicating the role that this parameter played in catalytic activity. The possible reason for the reduced activity can be explained due to the gaseous diffusion out of the pores during the thermal treatment resulted to surface pores constriction or partial removal of the binding water molecules from the catalyst structure, that could possibly lead to the destruction of the catalyst and resulted to the formation of unknown species of metals bandings [23,52,53]. 3.3.2 Effect of molar ratio of methanol to waste cooking oil The investigation on the catalytic performance of the Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was carried out to measure the effect of molar ratio of methanol on WCO on FAME content. Formation of FAME depends on the excessive amount of methanol in the process where transesterification is a reversible reaction [54]. Hypothetically, in the increase in the methanol-to-oil molar ratio facilitates both the transesterification reaction and the conversion of triglycerides into monoglycerides. The solubility of glycerol in FAME could be facilitated by the formation of monoglycerides, which results in glycerolysis of FAME, thereby decreasing the product yield [13]. However, excessive methanol is not recommended for the purification process of the synthesized FAMEs because it decreases the yield; such decrease in due to the dilution effect of the catalyst, which results in the insolubility of methanol in oil, thereby wasting the materials [55]. In addition, a significant amount of energy is needed to recover a huge amount of unreacted methanol. In the current research, the methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 20:1 is the optimal ratio that produces 90% FAME content; further increase to 30:1 decreases the conversion to 65%. This observation is similar to the results of Phan et al. [56] wherein the conversion of WCO is 88wt.% at methanol-to-oil molar ratio of 8 and the yield decreases to 82wt.% with the increase of the molar ratio to 12 after the 80min reaction. Fig. 6(b) and Table 5 shows the FAME content profile obtained by changing the methanol-to-oil molar ratio. 3.3.3 Effect of catalyst loading During transesterification reaction, the amount of catalyst utilized influence the FAME content of methyl esters. This section focuses on the effect of catalyst dosage on the FAME content of WCO. The Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst loading of 1.0–5.0wt.% was utilized for the reaction. Fig. 6(c) and Table 5 show an increase in FAME content with the increase in catalyst loading; the highest FAME content (90%) was obtained when the catalyst loading was 3.0wt.% after 3h reaction time. At catalyst loading higher than 3wt.%, the FAME content was reduced. No significant change was found on the yield of ester from 90% (catalyst loading is 3.0wt.%) to 83% (catalyst loading is 4.0wt.%) with further increase in catalyst loading. The solubility of methanol in waste oil is due to its limited amount, and by increasing the catalyst dosage, more products were adsorbed and the yield of biodiesel decreased, which is in good agreement with previous studies [16]. The recognized stability of catalyst structure against the emulsification by the co-produced methanol could be expected because the XRD analysis results showed that this catalyst possesses highly crystalline cohered structure; results of the FTIR analysis also indicated the same molecular banding of the reused and fresh catalyst (Sections 3.1.2 and 3.1.3). This study showed that to avoid emulsion in the transesterification reaction, low catalyst loading should be employed; the optimum catalyst loading obtained for this reaction was 3.0wt.%. 3.3.4 Effect of reaction time Given that transesterificationis a reversible reaction, relatively long time is needed to reach its equilibrium state [57]. With the use of the WCO and Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst, the effect of reaction time at constant catalyst dosage was examined, as well as the obtained FAME content at 1–5h reaction time (Fig. 6(d) and Table 5). The increase in the reaction time enhanced the WCO conversion. The FAME content obtained at 1h was significantly improved when the reaction time was increased, which can be attributed to slow mass transfer during heterogeneous reaction. For example, the yield of methyl esters increased from 74% at 1h and peaked to 90% at 3h at 20:1 molar ratio; 83% FAME content was found at 4h reaction time. Compared with the other heterogeneous catalysts [22,58] with long reaction time, the catalyst in the present study produced high FAME content within a short period of time. 3.3.5 Influence of water content on the transesterification reaction The transesterification activity of the catalysts was affected by water contained in the oils; higher water content leads to a reduced catalytic activity. In particular, water content more than 3% can be easily obtained in waste cooking and oil and crude oils. Hence, the catalyst stability in water-containing reaction system is a considerable alternative [46]. Water content higher than 0.5wt.% in basic-catalyzed systems cause a linear decrease in the FAME yield because the basic site could interact with water molecules, resulting in saponification reaction[59]. Sabri et al. demonstrated the same action of activated carbon-based catalyst with high water content [46]. Activated carbon surface contains oxygen ions that extend its affinity toward water. Oxygen ions usually bind to the unsaturated carbon atoms, generating a variety of oxygen surface groups. These surface groups are not dispersed homogeneously on the surface of the activated carbon, but they are mainly exposed on the catalyst surface to adsorb water, thereby increasing the hydration on the active sites of the catalyst [46]. Chai et al. [60] developed Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 catalyst for transesterification reaction of Eruca sativa Gars oil that is unaffected by the presence of water. In the present study, the FAME content was investigated in the presence of water with the use of the Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 as a catalyst. As shown in Table 6 , the catalytic activity was unaffected by water content less than 0.8%; 85% of FAME content can still be achieved when 0.6% water was added to the WCO. The reaction yield seemed to be stabilized for more than 0.1% water content in the oil. This result indicated that the synthesized catalyst can be used for WCO transesterification with different water contents. 3.3.6 Catalyst stability and reusability The stability of the catalytic activity of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst was evaluated by the leaching and the reusability method. To justify the use of supported catalyst as a heterogeneous catalyst, the leaching test was performed for blank sample and Cs0.6Zr0.4O/Al2O3 catalyst. The leaching of aluminum-supported catalyst was tested by hot filtration method [46]. A mixture of solid catalyst (0.75g) and methanol (23mL) was heated at 65°C for 3h under constant stirring. Subsequently, the catalyst was filtered and methanol was added to the WCO. The mixture was used in transesterification reaction at 65°C for 3h. For the blank sample, fresh methanol and WCO mixture was subjected to the same reaction conditions described above. The blank sample suffered from ∼3% leaching, whereas the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst showed 10% leaching. Compared with the other supported catalysts, such as activated carbon and silica [46,61], the catalyst synthesized in this study showed minimal leaching because of the strong absorption of metals on the aluminum surface. The aluminum-supported catalysts are stable for hydrodechlorination of chlorobenzene [62] and transesterification of Jatrophacurcas oil [57]. The reusability of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated by utilizing the catalyst in four successive reaction runs (Table 7 ). After each reaction, the catalyst was filtered and washed thoroughly with a mixture of hexane and methanol to remove most of the polar and non-polar components from the catalyst surface. The catalyst was repeatedly used in a new reaction cycle for FAME synthesis. The optimum reaction conditions (i.e., 3wt.% catalyst loading, 20:1 methanol-to-oil ratio, and 3h reaction time) were employed. Table 7 shows that FAME content was reduced by ∼7% between the second and third run, which could be attributed to loss of active sites of the catalyst during washing. To determine the changes in textural and structural properties after the fourth recycle run, the spent catalyst was characterized. The XRD patterns of the spent and fresh catalysts were compared (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3); the stability of the crystalline structure of spend catalyst was confirmed (Fig. 2(b)). Similarly, results of the FTIR spectra analysis (Fig. 3(b)) for the fresh and the spend catalysts showed similarity in all of the important parameters, except for some new peaks at 1258, 1443, and 2924cm−1 observed for the used catalyst, which were attributed to the presence of symmetric and asymmetric CO2 stretch representing the CO or CO functional groups from the carboxylates [31]. The presence of these new peaks could be due to the adherence of the triglyceride and methanol components to the surface of the catalyst. Based on the FTIR and XRD analysis results (Fig. 2(b), Fig. 3(b)) the reusability of the catalyst (Table 7) could be attributed mainly to its structural stability under the reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions Al2O3-supported Cs x Zr y O catalyst was suitable for transesterification of WCO; high catalytic activity was observed in the production of FAMEs. Results of the investigations indicated that the activity of the unsupported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2) was lower than that of the supported catalyst (Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3) on the basis of FAME content during transesterification reaction under the same reaction conditions. The highest FAME content (90%) was obtained with the use of the Cs0.6Zr0.4O2/Al2O3 catalyst under the following reaction conditions: 3wt.% catalyst loading, 30:1 methanol/oil ratio, 3h reaction time, and at constant temperature of 65°C. The catalyst could be easily recovered and it was reusable in the transesterification reaction for at least four cycles. Thus, FAME production with the use of Cs x Zr y /Al2O3 as heterogeneous catalyst exhibits good potential because of the easy catalyst preparation. In addition, the catalyst can produce high amount FAME within short reaction time at ambient conditions. coredata.dc:description: An impregnation method was used to develop a reusable and highly active heterogeneous catalyst (Cs x Zr y /Al2O3) with different Cs/Zr molar ratio (0.3≤ x, y ≤0.7). The catalyst activity was evaluated in the transesterification of waste cooking oil (WCO) with methanol for the synthesis of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs). A typical Cs0.6Zr0.4/Al2O3 catalyst was characterized for physical and chemical properties in terms of the amount of FAME produced. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method, X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, basic strength analysis, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy were utilized in the characterization of the catalysts. The effects of different process variables of transesterification reaction, such as methanol-to-WCO ratio (10:1–30:1), catalyst amount (1w/w–5w/w oil), and reaction time (1–5h), on the catalyst performance were investigated. During 3h reaction time 90%FAME content was produced at 65°C with 20:1 methanol-to-WCO molar ratio and 3wt.% catalyst loading. Results of the reusability tests indicated that the solid catalyst can be re-used for four batch cycles. Also, the catalyst exhibited good tolerance toward 0.8w.% water, without significant changes in the FAME content.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active alumina-supported Cs–Zr mixed oxide catalysts for low-temperature transesterification of waste cooking oil
